description:
Dining area: place could use a clean and touch up. You are able to see the kitchen wherever you sit in the place, so it is fairly small. They were not playing any music, but it was interesting to people-watch through the glass window. They could improve on this a little. Maybe some interesting things to look at.

Staff: very helpful and were working hard to please their customers.

Food: we ordered the orange chicken, side of rice, and  wonton soup. This was all 25$ portion sizes are medium and satisfying. No complaint about the food. If I were to be picky, I'd say the rice could have been more moist. 

I would definitely return again.
author: Mickey B.

description:
Rude Chinese lady!
She just wanted to get me to order stuff and bag em. The roasted duck was thrown into the box with low-quality packing material and did not answer to things I was asking about food. Just money minded and no proper customer experience.
Food was not that great. I will not try again.
author: Pruthviraj N.

description:
WORSTSERVICE and the Food is ehhhhh.... nothing memorable, we came here with a large party and they told us "supposedly" they don't do family style. We usually go to Kam Lol Resturant (less than a block away- but they were closed on Thursdays). Decided to go to BowHon wished we didn't! 
Again, food was ehh
Service HORRIBLE! 
Over priced for basic food. They get their money from Tourist. Not Euthentic food.
author: Rosa P.

description:
Nothing memorable sums it up for this restaurant that looks like a small place but when you walk upstairs to use the restrooms, you will note the large banquet room/additional sitting area they have.

We walked in for a quick early dinner. Promptly seated. They a few other tables occupied. We were tended to right away, the server was very friendly and helpful. We ordered half Peking duck ($30), cube steak with Chinese vegetables (it was only Buk Choi), and seafood fried rice with gravy on top. The total came out to $64 for two people with top $75 for two with food that was so so

The Peking duck was a disappointment as t was the least flavor and crispness I have ever experienced. Steak cubes were not cooked well and they were large enough that you needed a knife to cut them to avoid chewing on a large piece of meat!! The fried rice with gravy had too much watery gravy.

All together, other than good service, there wasn't anything that I would call good or great. A shame with all the restaurants in the area, they could still have businesses that lack Good to Great quality.
author: Mehrnaz H.

description:
Eenie, meenie miney, moe

Since I'm not from San Francisco just how does one choose a good Chinese restaurant in Chinatown?? Many of them have their menus posted outside their windows for tourist and passerby to see, right?? They all have a variety of noodles, fried rice, beef, chicken, and pork dishes but how do I know what restaurants are good? We looked down the street and checked out the menu of this restaurant and as we had just barely started looking at the menu from their window the host came outside and motioned for us to come inside... uh, okay? At the time there was only one other customer dining inside.

We went in and were given a menu to look at. Hubby and I have our favorite Chinese food dishes that we order all the time when dining at a Chinese restaurant but this time we had their "dinner for 2" special for $26.95. The special came with wonton soup, pork chow mein, spring egg rolls, beef broccoli, and fortune cookies (not sure why they would add fortune cookies to the menu as if it counts, I thought that was standard). 

The food tasted okay. Nothing that prompted for a second visit. Didn't like the egg rolls, tasted different from what my taste buds were used to. The fried rice and beef broccoli were decent but the chow mein was tasteless with lots of bean sprouts which hubby didn't like too much and the portions were small. The place filled up eventually because the host would do like what they did to us and he'd go outside and tell them to come in while people would just check out the menu from the window. So weird also that some restaurants were closed in the height of dinner time. Did I miss a Chinese holiday? 

There are so many Chinese restaurants in Chinatown that it's easy to bypass this one over another one.

Review #0917
author: May A.

description: While doing the tourist thing in Chinatown the family needed lunch.  With a number of small little eateries to choose from, we randomly chose Bow Hon and I think we scored!  Like most of the restaurants in Chinatown, it's small and basic expect your server to be speaking English as a second language.  This place was legit.  The staff was friendly and got us seated and took our order quickly.  I went with the Crispy Chicken and again I scored with that choice.  Basically you get a whole chicken cut into sections with the skin being perfectly crispy and crunchy.  It was moist and tender with a great crunch to the skin.  I devoured it.  It was a great lunch and I would go back in a heartbeat!
author: Shelby B.

description: Amazing food. It may look sketchy on the outside, but it was great inside. It was also fast service. We ordered the chicken dumplings, chicken fried rice, and the pork shumai, and it was all amazing. Would go back.
author: Cara C.

description: I CAN NOT believe I have to give them a one star. Bad experience. If it's ur first time walk out! Rude, small portions, bad service, food was bland and last but not least the waiter told me that I had to tip her 15 or 19 percentage of the meal. I was not impressed by the food.
author: J M.

description:
My first time in Chinatown and we stopped in for a quick lunch. The lady was very prompt and professional. The food came quick and was good. We had the Mongolian beef which the meat was tender and not too spicy. The pork fried rice was good, maybe a bit heavy on the salt. The egg rolls were very fresh tasting. My only disappointment was the wonton soup as it was bland and too watery. 
It's small in size and a bit run down but I would not hesitate to go back should I be in the area.
author: Kym S.

description:
Horrible place, they ripped me off like I was their last customer ever. Rice was $4? For a damn tiny white rice bowl. The fish I order with "market price" was like $40, and it was undercooked. Never would go back to this place again, and I would highly recommend to check prices if you must eat here

P/S: as soon as I finished my review I had to run to the bathroom ‍
author: Nghi T.

description:
I'm reading the reviews and I can see how this place can rip people off, but I've always had a good experience.  The food is pretty good and I have my lunch meetings here.  It usually is fairly uncrowded and they have wifi.  The food comes quickly, and I've had no complaints from my clients about the food.  

The dim sum here is lacking, so if you're looking for dim sum you should look somewhere else.  I always get the beef dishes here and some rice.  

This is a good fix if you're hungry for some traditional Chinese dishes.  
Great for tourist who just want to slide in for a quick meal.  Obviously read the reviews and make sure you know what you're getting into.  It's no magnus opus of a restaurant, but It's pretty good for what it is.  

It's a restaurant on a busy chinatown st with heavy tourist traffic, but they serve good food and a relax atmosphere.
author: Justin L.

description:
Service was really bad. I ordered dessert and was served first, the only food that was worth eating was the ice cream and it wasnt even from the restaurant. The food there was really expensive so was the tip i even found a shell in my fried rice, i was even ask to pay a $7 tip that was not worth it, not even worth going into the restaurant. The food was just bad, oil was leaking out of the plate. Tea wasnt even free if i had a choice to rate the restaurant I would have rated it below 0 stars 

P.S. put this review on my gravestone
author: John S.

description: Decent enough and quick. Not going to win any awards, but the place was clean and staff friendly.  Main room is small, upstairs either for parties or evenings. Mix of clay pot, standard Cantonese, and some assorted "usuals"
author: Mark L.

description: Walking through Chinatown looking for a place to eat. Dim Sum was great. Mixed chow mein had good flavor just not enough meat, was left with bok choy and noodles after first go around.
author: Toni C.

description: Great find. Will be back. Food was lite and not over powering with traditional flavors.
author: Grant G.

description: We had the full duck, BBQ pork (Char Shu), Mongolian Beef and a plate of Chinese Broccoli. All were excellent. The Duck was moist and tender. The Char Shu is some of the best I have had. Having lived in Hong Kong for several years my standards are pretty high. Wonderful. Highly recommended!
author: Jared M.

description: It's a hole in the wall but well worth it. We almost passed it when the young man came out and let us know they had room. The place is small but cozy. Service is super fast. We did the dinner for 2 ...+  depending on how many people joined us.  After the Chinese New Year parade we ran over there and landed us a table.  The food  is served is good portions. It does not taste like fast food. Sides like potstickers, egg rolls, and prawns are amazing!  Lastly because it's so much food that we end up taking a To Go box .  Great prices. Excellent service and food.
author: C M.

description: In town for a concert and our accommodations are close to Chinatown. Wandered in the Bow Hon for a quick lunch and ordered the vegetable chow mein and beef chow fun. Chow mein was saturated in soy sauce and vegetables were overcooked. Chow fun was good though. Touristy ambiance (expected).
author: Juan B.

description: The food is bad, we were charged double on the cost of the soup which tasted so bland and to top it off, the waitress that does not speak English added the tip to herself without even consulting us. I gave her the tip anyway but I'm not coming back. BEWARE OF THIS RESTAURANT or just don't go here.
author: Ed D.

description:
Just went here today for lunch, my Thai wife and her friend fresh from Thailand and myself. I ordered noodle soup with chicken, salt and pepper pork and 2 orders of steamed rice, came out to $30. I had quick figured in my head around $25 because I ordered the $5.95 won ton soup without won tons, only noodles but with chicken, upon further calculations the zinged me another $12-$14 for the soup.

And after ordering she tries to tell me we didn't order enough, well yeah with your skimpy dishes and fowl smelling chicken....

but the price (even though high) is not my complaint. When the soup came out the first words out of our friends mouth was the chicken is not fresh and my wife quickly agreed, being Thai and from the country they have a very sensitive nose to these types of smells. 

I never send food back, that is my practice and I don't waver from that and this was no exception. We ate around the chicken, the pork was half decent but pretty skimpy for a $14 dish. my only recourse is to tell about my story here
author: Rukus H.

description: The service and atmosphere were ok, we were particularly bothered by the very annoying lady greeter who hustled us very hard while we were reading the menu outside to the point that we almost didn't go in, but whatever this place lacked in sophistication, it made it up in delicious food. We tried the Mongolian beef, crispy skin chicken, and the house fried rice, all classic and relatively simple dishes that we had tried many times at other places, and we were really pleased. The only minor discrepancy was the Mongolian beef was a little too salty, but still delicious.
author: Kyle N.

description: Came here for lunch and ordered the family dinner for 4 and it was HORRIBLE!!! The servings were so little and the chow mien was EXTREMELY oily, fried rice were EXTREMELY salty, eggrolls were watery as if it was frozen prior to cooking, and the utensils were oily and unsanitary. The waiter was rude and almost hit my husband's head with a bowI. Lastly we were FORCED TO TIP 15%. I tipped the waiter a couple dollars even though everything was horrible and she had the audacity to chase me outside the restaurant and demand more!. I was boiling mad! STAY AWAY!
author: Pajhuabteeb Y.

description:
Jeez! It finally dawned on me that the years have sneaked up on me. When I say I have been patronizing Bow Hon for a long time, I do mean a long time. I don't just mean years but decades. Yes, without being too specific.... multiple decades! Bow Hon and I go waaaay back.... back to the days of Nancy Kwan in Flower Drum Song. What? You don't remember Flower Drum Song? We are talking about Grant Avenue, San Francisco, CA, USA. http://youtu.be/Qzv_qAlDZyA Grant is a touristy thoroughfare in Chinatown where BH is located, lined with dragon-entwined lampposts during Chinese festivals and jammed with restaurants, quaint shops selling furniture, fabrics, souvenirs and knickknacks etc from China, Hong Kong and Taiwan.
 
BH is in the heart of Chinatown. So don't expect anything fancy. BH was closed recently for a remodel and all they did to the interior was the bare minimum...a clean up, a new coat of paint and some furniture rearrangement. The façade remained divey and the decor was still bare bones. It was kind of like Sam Wo, where the food was better than the ambiance.  The servers are the nicest ladies and even though English is barely spoken, it is not difficult to communicate with them.

The clay pot rice was undoubtedly BH's specialty from time immemorial. We went off the menu and ordered the classic Salted Fish with Pork Patty ($18.95 for 2), one of the most well loved Cantonese dishes. Traditionally, some bits of fat are preferred in the pork patty so the meat will stay moist and flavorful. However I applauded BH to be so thoughtful to use lean pork for me maybe because they recognized me as a long time customer. Paired with the pork was the salted fish in all its fragrance and saltiness. The rice was cooked in the clay pot creating the much-coveted crusty layer of slightly charred rice at the bottom (farn jiu). Think Rice Krispies.... only better! At the end of the meal, chicken broth with chopped cilantro was poured over the hardened rice crust and scraped off. That provided yet another end-of-the-meal treat.

I can't believe I ordered the Cold Boiled Chicken (half-$10.95) with a side of Ginger and Scallions sauce. The cooking method is homey, simple and a favorite among gong-gongs (grandpas) and poh-pohs (grandmas) from the old country and you guess it.... Me as well! BH uses "yellow feathered chicken" (wong mo gai). This chicken is usually free ranged, smaller in size and has less fat. There is less meat, a little tougher but a lot more flavorful especially eaten with ginger and scallions. The chicken was really an accompaniment for the lo mein I ordered ($8.95). The noodles were tossed in soy, sugar and oyster sauce. I love to sprinkle some white pepper on the noodles, slurp them in between bites of the chicken, sucking the bones and gnawing on the wings. I hope I didn't sound too gross but that was the way to do it!

BH has definitely withstood the test of time. It is with sadness and nostalgia to see the disappearance of so many iconic old school restaurants from the Chinatown dining scene recently. Time marches on ruthlessly, stops for no one, restaurants included. BH has created a well deserved  'clay pot rice' niche and hopefully they can continue to uphold this tradition for many more generations to come.
author: Geoff G.

description:
MAJOR WARNING:
1. May be OVERCHARGED
because orders are only written in Chinese and they seem to have a history of giving people the wrong checks (form Yelp reviews), making people pay for more than they ordered. This happened to me today but fortunately I read Chinese so I told the lady she made a mistake.

2. Being forced to TIP
For their POOR to mediocre service, they force you to give them tips. Don't get me wrong, despite the kind of service I received, I was going to give this lady a 15% tips. But I was going to wait for her to give me the change first from my cash payment and then leave some tips on the table before leaving. When I put my cash payment on the check, she came and actually CHECKED (honestly, counted in front of me) how much I gave and when she realized I only paid roughly for the amount of the grand total, she ANGRILY said, "NEED TO GIVE TIPS." (whuuut?!)
Dumbfounded, I said I was going to do so before I leave, but she insisted I do that before so I still ended up giving it to her together with the rest of the payment. The funny part was that while I was whipping out my money, she was still checking up on me to see if she was receiving her tips. Does she know that tips are OPTIONAL?!?! It's a norm, yes, but it is also a norm to NOT GIVE tips when the service sucks. And who yells at their customers to pay tips?!

3. BLEH service
They're kind of short-staffed which resulted in a rather slowww service. I understand they may be stressed/tired but that's no excuse for treating customers poorly. So do them a favor and don't patronize this restaurant, in this way, they'll have enough hands and energy to deal with the customers they have.

Food:
The food was somewhere between decent to good. However, if you take into consideration of having to deal with the customer service provided here, well then, the rating for this place just dropped from good to horrible.

CONCLUSION:
DONT COME HERE.
author: Jennifer C.

description: Tiny hole in the wall with only 5 tables.  the food is delicious!.  I had the oyster and roast pork clay pot. it was perfect.  great flavors. the staff were friendly and attentive. we will come back next time we are in San Francisco
author: Christopher Z.

description: I was looking for some good ol' comfort hot and sour soup. My friend and I wandered into Chinatown hoping for a hole in the wall type of spot. Unfortunately, this is not it. I ordered the hot and sour soup ($7.50) and Spring Egg Rolls ($5). We also each got a cup of tea, which was okay. I'm not sure if there's refills on it either. When the food came out, it was the smallest portion of food I've ever seen. For a Chinese spot, I usually find myself with leftovers, but definitely not the case. The spring rolls were chewy and the sweet and sour sauce that accompanied it were very watery. Even though it only came with three rolls, I was barely able to finish because it just tasted like fried dough. As for the hot and sour soup, it was okay. It sufficed my need, but wasn't satisfying and came in the smallest bowl ever. Do not even think about sharing your dishes here, which is usually the way Chinese places are --family-style. Lastly, it's cash only. I don't even know what was calculated, but I ended up spending $20 in the end. I have never spent so much money on simple Chinese food. I'm disappointed.
author: Cindy Z.

description:
Poor first experience w/ Chinese food in San Fran.

Terrible service. Food was not all it was hyped to be. I tried this based on trip advisor ratings and was disappointed. 

We had the chili tofu and eggplant. Both were mediocre. Rice was nothing to rave about. I wouldn't come here again.
author: David L.

description: Over priced, bad food, WORST SERVICE EVER. They made us get up in the middle of eating and move to another table. The waitress spilled ice water all over me and didn't even notice and then came in the middle of our meal and took all of our plates to another table and made us get up and move, very rude! Also we only ordered two plates but some how the meal ended up being 30 dollars...I would have been way more satisfied even just going to Taco Bell but instead I'm laying in bed with an awful stomach ache.
author: Zoe W.

description: We ordered two roast duck noodle soups.The price is quite high compared to other similar restaurants in Chinatown but I have no complaint about that. The bizarre thing is the lady waitress told us how much to tip ! She did that in front of the cashier and he acted like that is normal.
author: Phuong M.

description:
Food was okay,  nothing spectacular but not bad either. However for the price i don't think it's worth it. Hong Kong hot milk tea was wonderful though. 
Service was not good. It was not super busy but had to ask for more water because the waiter never came to check our table. And I don't know why it took them so long to get the check.
author: Charlie L.

description:
My parents and I decided to have a spur of the moment lunch walking through Chinatown.  We stumbled upon this spot and I should have looked at yelp.  When we walked in they took at look at us and sat us upstairs when there were available seats downstairs.  My personal opinion is it was because we weren't Chinese or Caucasian.

We stood around for 3 minutes because there was only 1 server upstairs and she was too busy to seat us.  After we were seated and given a menu it took 20 minutes to come back and take our order.  We asked for tea and never got it.  We had to walk up to the hot water dispenser, open a kettle, pour water and put a tea bag in it.  We also had to get our own napkin, plate, and chopsticks.

Order:
1 steam black bass
1 Chinese broccoli with beef
1 clay pot special
3 individual servings of rice
1 pot of tea
Total bill was $102!!!

The price of the fish was 60 dollars.  29.99/lbs is what they are claiming and that it was a 2lbs fish.  That's complete bs!  They never told us the seasonal price and never told us how many lbs. the fish will be.  She was so distracted that she just put the order in, instead of confirming back with us what it will be.  The fish came and our mistake for touching/eating it before confirming the price.

The bill came written in Chinese and we didn't understand a thing they were trying to tell us.  We refused to get ripped off, so I compromised to charge us 1lbs. for the fish which clearly was!  My point being is they can't just list seasonal pricing, don't inform us of what that pricing is (it was written anywhere on the menu, and there wasn't a seasonal sign posted on the fish tank), and then just throw out a bogus number of what the fish weighed.

Called SFPD, long story short they mediated for us and the fish was dropped to 1lbs. on the bill.  They were arguing back and forth with the translating officer and was told to hush it because they kept interrupting when we were speaking.  Other patrons had issues with their bill and I even cited yelp reviews of others being ripped off.  An officer also stated that's the only spot in Chinatown they are always getting called to.  Waited 2 hours to sort things out, and NEVER AGAIN will we ever go back there.

If I had the time I'd stand out there letting everyone know to check their bill twice before paying.
author: Christopher P.

description:
I was in Chinatown with family a couple of weeks ago and stopped in here for some food. We were seated right away and the lady that seated us was also our server. This place is really small but the service was good and it had a good vibe.
We had fried rice, chow mien, roasted duck, orange chicken, and Kung pao prawns. (The prawns were more like shrimp but still good.)
The food was all delicious! ONLY complaint is it was a little disappointing that everything came out individually instead of all together. We just kinda snacked on stuff as it came out until we had everything to make our plates.
 Overall the food was really good, and I'll be back.
author: Amanda M.

description:
We were enticed inside by an enthusiastic woman out front so we thought we would give it a try. Even though it was for dinner we wanted to try the dim sum. We were told that all dim sum after breakfast was $1 extra per plate but that didn't stop us. Everything we ordered was excellent (except for the fried onion pancake, don't get that). We ate pork shu mei, hot and sour soup, sweet pork dumpling, potstickers, shrimp dumpling, and the best was the sesame red bean ball. All amazing!!! 

The actual restaurant is very plan-that is why it's not 5 star!
author: Kimberly H.

description:
This restaurant features home style Tai-Shan cuisine, specializing in claypot cooking with the coveted crispy rice on the bottom and meat on the top. We were pleasantly surprised - clean, friendly and not watered down. Stick with the traditional dishes. 

What we ordered - 

- Seaweed soup - they add peas and carrots which is not typical, but the kids liked it

- Pork hock cooked in vinegar - few places even make this dish now. Brought back strong memories of childhood meals for my husband. Just perfect - sweet, sour, fall off the bone tender! Just the sauce over rice is so satisfying!

- Chicken, sausage, and mushroom claypot   - my husband practically licked the pot. Dark saucy, tasty, and plenty of crispness on the bottom

- Dry cooked green beans with garlic - plenty of garlic! 

- Fried shrimp - very lightly battered whole fresh shrimp with head, tail, and shells on, just as expected. Most restaurants over batter, but this place did it just right!

One star deducted for the overbearing lady standing outside who was probably scaring off customers more than she was bringing in. I'm glad she did not scare us off tonight!
author: Jenny C.

description: BEWARE, this place is not WORTH what you pay, Do Not be lured by the lady that will come to you to get you to come in.
author: Juan J.

description:
Yelp reviews and pictures claimed that this place specializes in claypot rice.  I would say otherwise.  Their claypot rice is expensive at around $18.  We got the chinese sausage and smoked pork one.  This is very traditional and a good way to tell if a restaurant truly specializes in claypot rice.  The waitress did warn us that it would take some time to make which should be expected for this dish.  When it came out she offered to cut up the meat,  mix the rice for us, and serve it.  The claypot was filled with so little rice.  And worst yet, the rice was not all the crunchy nor was it flavorful.  And I didn't think it was possible, but the sausage and pork was also bland tasting.  This was a total let down.  

If you're looking for a claypot restaurant, go find another one.  I still have yet to find an authentic and good one in SF.
author: Jenny Y.

description: Please please don't go here ! I order orange chicken and I found a spider on my plate, when I saw it I immediately called the server he took my plate right away and refuse to give it to me back so I wouldn't take a picture.
author: Freddy P.

description: We were starving and having difficulty figuring out which of the many restaurants to pick, so when I saw Kimberly H.'s review and the same enthusiastic woman in front of this restaurant, we decided to give it a try.  I explained as we entered that half of our family are vegetarians, and we were assured that wouldn't be a problem, which it wasn't.  The woman who ushered us in and seated us made sure to tell the waitress about our dietary preferences, which was appreciated.  The food came very quickly and was tasty.  And yeah, the check was written in Chinese characters, but that didn't bother me at all, since um ... we were in SF Chinatown!  Were we overcharged?  Didn't seem like it, although the fact is that in any major tourist location (be it Chinatown, Fisherman's Wharf, or wherever) you are going to pay more that you might otherwise, so bring a sandwich along if you don't like it.  Also, if I am going to pay a little more, I can assure you I'd rather the money go to an independent business than somewhere like the Hard Rock Cafe.
author: Alexandra B.

description:
As a tourist, I'm always hesitant to try out a food place I haven't thoroughly checked out. 
But this place.... 
The sweetest older lady caught my attention as she handed us a menu and beckoned my family to come in. 
This place was delicious! The tea was the perfect. Very simple but definitely a good place for comfort  Food was fantastic and if provided such a quiet, quaint experience. The service was a little slow but the food came in at a fantastic pace. Definitely going to miss this place and check it out when we come back to the bay.
author: Alex B.

description: DO NOT eat at this restaurant!!! I looked at the menu outside and the hostess/waitress invited me in. As I sat down, I ordered pot stickers because I love them and you can't go wrong. WRONG. They came out promptly but were shimmering with grease and were clearly overcooked. I didn't even need to take a bite, which I didn't. I thought I'd be safe by ordering the tofu and greens. The dish was ok, just very average. The waitress never checked on me and in fact stood outside the restaurant when I was ready for the check (there was only one other party of 3 in the restaurant). Finally I got the check and paid $24.80 for very little food. I agree with other reviewers: a ripoff. But the worst part was when I stood to put on my coat, she came over and picked up the money and said, "Tip, tip." I actually didn't want to leave a tip since I hardly ate anything -- she didn't even ask why I didn't touch the potstickers and left half the other dish -- and the service was terrible. She positioned herself so that I couldn't leave and wrote on her hand, Tip. The other people were looking over. Unbelievable!!!! I lived in Taiwan for a year so I am familiar with Chinese culture. I was polite, didn't complain about anything but was treated very rudely. I just wanted to get out of there. Do not go to this restaurant!!
author: Jana E.

description: Most recent visit (January 2017) had to go back to Bow Hon to have some delicious eats. Ordered wonton soup, egg rolls, chicken chow mein, and a bunch of dim sum. So good. Even the kids love it! I left my heart at Bow Hon in SF.
author: Coño G.

description:
Amidst the Chinatown usuals of dim sum, chop suey, Cantonese and other regional specialities, Bow Hon has stood alone for many years (I've been coming here since 1982 or so). The specialty not to be missed are the dishes braised in clay pots. On this visit I had my favorite, the vegan monk's stew. It is a lovely blend of dried mushrooms of several varieties, tofu, snow peas, green onions, bok choy, and rice noodles is a subtle braising broth. It is eaten over rice, and I finished by eating the well flavored rice noodles.

My only complaint on this visit was the inability to get the check, get the server to collect it (a cook ended up doing it), and as I walked out, the server chased me down, thinking I had stolen her pen, made hilarious by the fact that she could not speak English. Finally all was resolved, and I refuse to downgrade 5 stars that represent years of good meals for one lapse in service.
author: John S.

description:
They LITERALLY tried to defraud my family. If I could give negative stars, I would.

My family and I were walking around Chinatown and decided to have dinner at Bow Hon because the menu looked interesting. I, unfortunately, decided not to check with my trusted Yelp before going in. 

Food wise, it deserves all the low ratings that it has received. Nothing special and I honestly suspect that some of the ingredients they used might have been going bad. We also ordered a clam dish in which more than half the clam shells were empty when the plate was put on our table. 

The real kicker came when the check arrived though. At first my family couldn't understand why the check was so expensive. When we asked a hostess to run it through with us, it became clear. A line item labeled "Rice F" was apparently a 17.27% TIP that was automatically included in our bill that they didn't even tell us about. At that time, we were a little bit annoyed at the underhanded tactics but we paid the bill. When my mother commented to the hostess how the tip should be voluntary, the hostess literally walked off in the middle of the sentence. Yup, we were paying 17% for that type of service. 

But that's not the defrauding I'm talking about. Right after the waitress walked off, we hear the lady from the next table exclaim that they miscalculated her bill and overcharged her by $4. You can pretty much guess what happened next. We took out a calculator and added our bill up. Surprise, surprise, we were overcharged as well. It was only a difference of $2 but at that point, it was about the principle of NOT DEFRAUDING YOUR CUSTOMERS. The rudest part is after they recalculated both our bills (my family and the family at the next table), they still had the audacity to charge the same tax and MANDATORY tip. Suffice it to say that neither I or my family will be going back. EVER.
author: Wanting Z.

description:
Came in by chance, ordering was fast, clean and spotless place as I observed while waiting for our food which came quick!  Food was delicious, doesn't make you sleepy nor is it salty!  Nice little gem tucked in the Chinatown area.  

I recommend this place for everyone who likes a deal, good food, a friendly face and a comfy eating environment!
author: May T.

description:
Spur of the moment decision to eat here because I saw that they had ginger and scallion crab, which is one of my favoriteeeessss. it was delicious! Can't say much about anything else though, that's basically all we ordered - crab, rice, and our drinks. 

The server was nice and I spoke to a chef for a little bit, asking how the hell one makes the sauce for this dish.... It's pretty simple actually. 

Anyway, the place is small, bathroom's up the semi-steep stairs on the second floor, across from a second dining room. 

So, really I'm giving the crab 5 stars, but am deducting one... Because we saw a large bug on the wall... Eeek
author: Geri F.

description:
A golden standard of SF's Chinatown for clay-pot cooking. The atmosphere could be better but it's pretty typical of no-frills Chinese--especially Cantonese--places in Chinatown and has been around for decades. I don't think people should judge Bow Hon on atmosphere because it's simply not the type of place you come for a posh atmosphere: if you want that, go to Tommy Toy's. 

The quality of food varies but the clay-pot dishes and seafood in general are the best bets and what people come here for time and again. The clams in black bean sauce is also a favorite. If you get clay-pot, go for seafood over anything else. People on here seem to complain that Bow Hon is overpriced and it seems a bit high on some items, certainly.  

Golden Flower Vietnamese Restaurant, also in Chinatown but a Viet restaurant with clay-pot cooking Viet-style, is more fairly-priced and probably better overall quality, truth be told.
author: Mike W.

description:
Please rethink your visit here.
Very disappointing.
This place has a terrible attitude.
Every low rating about this place in Yelp made sense after my experience here.
$1.50/person for tea. when other places just give it to you for free.
Here's My Story:

I was walking by this restaurant and looking for a place to grab some dinner.
The lady on the side walk approached me with a smiley face.
So my friend and I decided to walk in.
I went to the washroom as my friend was looking at the menu.
We decided it was not a good place to eat, because the menu looked EXTRA expensive.
It was going to charge us $1.50/person just for jasmine tea when other places just offer it for free as you are seated. And they charge $4 for soda.
And when you ask something about the menu, because everything is mostly written in Chinese, the lady acts like she speaks little English, and adds it to the menu without our confirmation.
And the grand finale, as we were getting up to leave, the Chinese lady, blocked my way close up to my face, in such a disrepectful way, with her tone really angry and aggressive, said that I had to pay $2 for using the bathroom.
So I asked is that $2 charge stated in the rule, she said that it is stated in the rule book of the government somewhere in good English.
 I was led in by the owner's persuasion and decided to leave because I decided it was a terrible place. 
It was not like I walked into the restaurant just to take a piss and dip.
The place is run by those typical set of smiley faced people in Chinatown that would just yell at you if you decide not to spend your money. You know what I'm talking about.
This place gave me and my friend a good laugh.
I am really glad that I decided to leave this place.
I am giving a one star because there is no 0 stars or negative stars.
I hope you good fellas out there choose from the many of the better restaurants in China Town.
author: Paul K.

description:
We were walking around China Town waiting around for the line to shorten at the best place in town to get some egg custard tarts, when we were overcome with a craving for some dim sum. We were planning to eat some sweet egg custard tarts, it's natural to want to have something savory before eating that sweet dessert. (Hehehe.)

Anyway, we were walking up and down the street and not sure where to go, because there are so many similar restaurants, and we don't speak any Cantonese, Mandarin, etc.. The lady trying to get us to come into the restaurant was pretty persistent here, so we decided to give this place a try. 

We were on the move, because the line at the bakery was pretty long, so we got some dim sum to go. We only wanted some xiu mai (pork and shrimp in a wonton wrapper that has been steamed), so we got a couple orders to go. Service was quick, but the xiu mai were rubbery and bland. The shrimp was not flavorful or fresh either. 

I know this restaurant has been here for a long time and is an institution in China Town, and I really wanted to like it. Maybe next time. Perhaps we'll be here for dinner the next time, maybe dinner is better than dim sum...
author: Anh D.

description: My friend and I came here to eat dinner one night.  We decided on the dinner for two menu.  To my dismay,  when the girl brought our individual bowl of Wonton soup to us,  there was ONLY 1 Wonton in the bowl.  Then later,  they brought out 2 egg rolls.  Enough said,  this place was a whole lot better in the 80s. Now,  they must have geared it as a tourist trap.  I don't see many locals eating there anymore.
author: Clarice L.

description:
As mentioned by Geoff G. (http://www.yelp.com/user_details?userid=AA4EmkZwGfgpezbJH90WDw), there are few old school eateries in Chinatown these days.  New Lun Ting and the Empress of China, dinosaurs from the iconic '70's, are, along with this Grant Avenue staple, fading beacons of the neighborhood dining scene.  
As the food trends came and went, they lasted the test of time.  Sadly, Empress' impending closure will bring the number to two.
This small spot used to be next to a corner western grocery store (now a tourist gift store) to the left and an Orange Julius (now a coffee/snack shop) to the right.  My parents took us here for occasional family dinners to enjoy their specialties, clay pot dishes.  We used to order family style and have Sizzling chicken in gravy (jie jie gai) or beef brisket with radish chunks, Cantonese comfort food staples.
Unfortunately, these family dinners have become in home events so takeout meals are our norm.  Since the aforementioned don't taste the same, I order a medium or large Preserved duck and sausage clay pot rice (lap mei), depending on our party size.  The preserved meats comes in a flat clamshell takeout box on a small bed of rice; the majority of the rice came packed in a large paper takeout box; note:  the rice is not as crispy as some may like.  There is another box with lettuce with oyster sauce.  There is also a tall soup container with the rinsed rice remains (fan jiu) from the clay pot.  A medium feeds a family of four with the addition of one or two side dishes.  The magic to this dish is that the rice and the meats were cooked on medium heat in a clay pot so that the protein flavors permeate into the rice.  They include a small container (bowl, if dining in) of sweet soy sauce to enhance the taste.
Yes, they're still cranking out those clay pot rice orders, but don't wait too long as who knows how much longer they'll be there.
author: Mike C.

description: Amazing flavor and incredibly tender beef. Nice family owns the restaurant. Highly recommend!
author: Sara J.

description: Very good food. Service was good, but orders got messed up when busy. Dumpling were good. Enjoyed the house chow me in and pork fried rice.
author: Michael W.

description: Great food and customer service, but speak slowly to adjust for the language barrier.
author: T C.

description: I came to China Town with my parents to find a good spot to eat. So we came across this restaurant called Bow Hon. Maggie our server was really nice. We enjoyed everything here. My favorite is this Salmon fried rice. My parents wish to come back soon & so do I. I recommend others who lo e seafood to come to this place.
author: Shirley A.

description: We were looking for a reasonable Chinatown lunch experience.  The place was generally clean, white tablecloths with glass tops, small (only about 4 -5 tables on the first floor), with some decor. We ordered the Mongolian beef and some fried rice.  The fried rice was typical, and the mongolian beef a little too greasy for my taste.  My son had the Won Ton soup, and that was simple but tasted awesome!  I noticed the tea bag in my tea pot was Bigelow tea, so I wouldn't say the place is authentic, and there were no locals in the restaurant when we visited. Caters to the tourist clientele. If you're a little hesitant to try out a true Chinese foodie experience, but want the illusion, this might be the place for you.  We are still looking.....
author: Cathy G.

description: I can understand the service is lacking but I take as a language barrier. Food is really good! The steamed buns are okay. Very good food for a fair price :)
author: Maribel M.

description: Walked by and saw that it was packed so we popped in and I am so glad we did. Prawn in lobster sauce and War Wonton and it was absolutely amazing. I will definitely come back!
author: Rick F.

description: I came here for late night food close to closing time. I I got the Bow Hon special, which included pork mushrooms and seafood dumplings.  Service was fairly fast, the price was okay, and the food was super middle of the road. Not great, not terrible.
author: Joseph H.

description: Great clay pot rice place. The chicken clay pot rice is very saucy and they controlled the flame just right so that the bottom of the pot is just crispy and not burnt. The sausage clay pot is has amongst the most tender Chinese sausages I have tasted. Good pork trotters as well.
author: Yh G.

description: One of two of our favorite clay pot rice places within walking distance here. Always good hanging out with friends.
author: Hairy L.

description:
Came here because a friend of a friend was already inside. The place is fairly small. I looked at the menu and noticed the prices were kind of high for Chinatown, but still ordered a few plates. Each plate were tiny, about the size of a standard serving plate. The cheapest plates were already $9.

The service was new because they didn't know how to serve the clay pot. The service was slow because they took forever to fill the tea. 

The journey to the restroom was a big trip. Each floor has 10' ceilings and the restroom was on the 3rd floor. The men's restroom had a big window that one cannot easily close, so neighbors can easily watch a person doing their business. Even the door was hard to lock and open. 

Coming back down to the first floor, one can feel the heat from the stoves making one feel kind of dizzy or at least I was.
author: M C.

description:
The price is way too steep for what they serve.

The steamed fish was the best that we had out of everything, but it cost us $29.95, whereas a regular restaurant would be at most $15. Wtf?

Otherwise, the house-made bean curd over greens was the next best dish. That dish was gone fast.

Contrary to what everyone said about the clay-pot, it was not very good. The chicken was way overcooked, and the overall dish was just not that flavorful, though there was plenty of salt and msg!

Everything else was just okay-tasting. And expensive. On top of that, the waitress kept pressing us to order more food.

Best that this place is avoided.
author: Dianna D.

description: I have to say it is the worst Chinese food I had eat in SFO......no in US!!! the only taste is salty! Nothing else!! Please do not go......never ever!
author: Zheng Z.

description:
I had ordered a delivery of shrimp fried rice from here. They were prompt in their delivery but the food lacked quality. the food was very oily and could eat more than a couple of mouthfuls.

I would have rated 1 star if not for the prompt delivery. Would never recommend.
author: Pradeep J.

description:
Got totally ripped off.  $6 for a few bites of rice noodle (the cheapest item in the world) and veggie dumplings (come on.. there's not even meat in here!).  I could get more food at the overpriced dim sum restaurant City View. see photo ~
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/AtU4bqmaF5Aw3zc1_n68Kg?select=zKEDkPELi9vZyUWk1e5HHA
author: s m.

description:
When my husband and were looking for someplace to eat in Chinatown, we were directed to the restaurants down Jackson St. While we were walking to Jackson St., a lady literally followed us 3 blocks telling us to go to her restaurant and how it's so good and a whole bunch of other broken english. It was quite annoying! So we brushed her off and went down Jackson and perused the menus of several restaurants. My husband really wanted to try claypot dishes so we went into one place to put our name down on a list. The list was too long and it was getting crowded in the waiting area so we decided to just head away from Jackson St. and look for other places. Problem was that we were there quite late and there weren't that many places anymore. So after awhile, we settled on Bow Hon and I'm glad we did!

Mustard green soup with salty egg was amazing. Beef with poached egg claypot and chicken with mushroom and chinese sausage claypot was also yummy. When we were done with the claypot, our server added a soup concoction to scrape the rice off the bowl. It was soooo tasty! Definitely better than expected! The place wasn't crowded, which I liked. It was small, but since we were basically the only ones in the restaurant, we received a more personal service.
author: Marie C.

description: Clay pot was ok; edible but not great for the price I'm paying (around $18.95 per clay pot).  There wasn't much flavor in any of the dishes except for saltiness and the only people I saw in the restaurant were tourists.  It just wasn't very satisfying food, given that the claypots are supposed to be their specialty.
author: Max M.

description: It sucks!!!!!! If people give the tips less than 15%, they won't let you go!!! And the foods not good at all!
author: Stephanie Z.

description: Excellent food, I loved watching the cook make different dishes.  He's very clean.  Food was very fresh, fast, and hot.  The service was superber and reasonably priced.
author: R S.

description: Ended eating at this place 6/5 Friday. They have a old lady on the sidewalk hawking menus and getting you to come in eat. They are quite pushy. Their menu is nothing to be excited about. They have limited dimsun items. They have three menus that could make it confusing for some. There are many other restaurants in the area that have great food. However if there is nothing else to eat, you can take a chance and eat here.
author: Maria D.

description:
The new Bruce Willis / Morgan Freeman / John Malkovich and Helen Mirren. movie " RED" was the great way to begin the evening -  if you like action and humor. The after movie hunger pangs were met with disappointment, when we decided to have Chinese food in China town and see some Chinese people, and walk the dirty garbage filled SF China Town streets.

Not to insult the "Americanized" version of Chinese food or fans thereof, we ordered the very traditional Beef Chow Fun, Seafood Chi Min (sp?) and Stuffed fried Tofu.

FOOD: not very good, with portions that were disappointing.  

Seafood Chi Min:  Seafood was not fresh, and on the verge of sponsoring a nasty case of food poisoning

Beef Chow Fun"  Not a plate of Fun. More like a plate of ho-hum. Beef marinated in oil ( to sponsor an artificial tenderness) and noodles that were purchased days ago and over-cooked ( read mushy ).

Stuffed Fried Tofu: Seafood stuffing ( kinda nasty ) not  fresh and good, Tofu - not bad. Dish is drowned in a salty brown gravy sauce of an undetermined origin. 

SERVICE: 

Serving the food by slamming it on the table (maybe to announce its arrival), server didn't even look at the table. Needed more tea, had to send up a flare. Yup, as one reviewer points out and I quote " It's a genuine Chinese restaurant....." .... well maybe they should get out more.

Hmmm, well got the check gave the money ( cash ) with a 15% tip. Got chased down the street by the Ms. waitress / cashier / manager saying we underpaid. Well the " 7 " at the end of the amount looked like a " 1 " so we treated it as a " 1 ". So, going back to the restaurant to settle the (miss) understanding of the poor writing of the bill, I review the bill more closely only to discover that it was not our bill. Based on the number of items, it was not our bill. Ms. waitress / cashier / manager then said we ordered all of these items, and yelled at me that I was trying to cheat her. 

Asking for an explanation for each item, it was clear and she admitted that this was the wrong bill. Of course our bill was less $.  Then in the moment of her innocent attempt to cheat me, and while accusing me of cheating her, she asked for more of a "service charge" ingrish translation: MORE TIP. I think she did this because her ruse didn't pay off. 

Summary: 

food 1* (badly prepared and small portions)
Service 0* (read above)
Ambiance of  the many 500 watt florescent lights 0* (nuf said)

Should have gone to the Sam Woh restaurant, at least knowing to expect: bad food, bad service, and bad environment. They do set expectation and do their best to fulfill their promise. Even Sam Woh's gets the 3.5 * yelp rating while this trap gets 3 * from yelp!

GO GO SAM WOH:

http://www.yelp.com/biz/sam-wo-restaurant-san-francisco#query:sam%20woh
author: Matsuo U.

description: The pork fried rice was really good noodles a bit salty but sesame chicken was very tasty.  Small place with out frills but decent for two hungry tourists.
author: Lynette C.

description:
In the neighborhood and went back for what else but their Shunde Delux Fish Salad (Medium $25.99).  This time, my dad was pretty disappointed in the dish overall.  It seemed like there was less fish this time and the general taste could have been better.

We also got two orders of Hong Kong-style Chow Mein, one with veggies and another with combination style.  My mom requested that they keep the noodles separate, that way the noodles don't get soggy too fast.  

The orders seemed a bit small for the price you pay.  Then again, they are located on Grant Street and it's a pricier location!

I got a pic of the fish salad this time!
author: Teri C.

description:
Wandering through SF Chinatown can be pretty daunting. Stretching 8 blocks long and 3 blocks wide, my friends and I were in awe of everything around us. It sure got us tired and hungry quick. We, then, had a difficult task of choosing from the endless number of restaurants. Since we could not collectively agree, we chose the restaurant that was right in front of us. What a f*cking mistake... haha

As we entered Bow Hon, it seemed relatively busy. The inside looked a bit run down; nothing out of the ordinary. Since we wanted to eat light, we ordered primarily from their dim sum menu. While we waited, they served us water. Oh my gawd! Microorganisms were floating at the top. Either they did not wash the cups thoroughly or they got us plain ol' unfiltered tap water. *gag* 

Fried Calamari - Sh*t was bland as f*ck. It was mostly fried batter with teeny pieces of squid. All for $6.95. Not worth it.
Shrimp & Pork Shumai - Not bad. A bit dry. Had better. 
Shrimp Dumplings - The shrimp was incredibly small.
Fookkin Rice - It was like eating a spoonful of salt. Just terrible.

Bottom Line: This place should be shut down for unsanitary conditions and serving atrocious food.
author: Foodie ..

description: By far the worst dim sum I have ever eaten, and I'm counting frozen microwave stuff. The dishes were all dirty. I was horrified when I looked in the teapot at all the fluff and dirt in there.
author: Ash H.

description:
Just because it's a Chinese restaurant situated on Grant Ave does not mean that it will cater to every tourist's need for chow mein and egg rolls.  Bow Hon has been around since the 80s (maybe even longer?).  My mom used to go here back in her college days.  They've specialized in claypot rice for years and it's such a good deal!  One giant claypot for 2 (can easily feed 3) also includes lao huo tang (a healthy soup of the day which is usually comprised of veggies, Chinese herbs, and chicken/pork/beef) and a plate of veggies.  My favorite claypots are the chicken (or frog if it's available) and mushroom and the ones made with preserved Chinese sausages, smoked pork, and smoked duck.  At the end of the meal, they pour in a ginger soup to mix with the burnt rice at the bottom of the claypot which makes for a great end-of-the-meal treat.

This is not a place to go for "Americanized" Chinese food.  They may serve egg rolls and potstickers for the unknowing tourists but that's not what they specialize in.  And no, it's not the fanciest establishment - it's a complete hole in the wall plastered with posters of dishes to appeal to the tourists.  I'm impressed that they've managed to keep their business running for so many years and to have fed our family a reasonably priced and tasty claypot rice for so long!
author: Joanne L.

description: Oh my god! Worst restaurant at Chinatown ever. Better save yourself a pleasant day by going somewhere else. Rude service for horrible food.
author: T? J.

description: Don't go there! I hope I can gave then negative stars! Everything so over priced, dishes looks totally different with menu, and so little. They charge $1.85 for a small small white rice. If u asked hot tea they will gave you a pot of tea with used tea leaves, you cannot test any tea flavor, and charge you $1.5 per person! So ridiculous! Services is so bad! Never go there!
author: JJ K.

description: suck forever...... just a few food, different between the picture on the menu. They put the used tea and charge you $1.50 for each person. WTF. Never saw that before. Won't go there again.
author: Yiming B.

description:
CLAY POT RICE!!!

That is the only thing that is good here and the only thing I order.  The decor leaves a lot to be desired but seriously people, you are in Chinatown.  You're not in some fine dining ultra-chic, modern establishment.  You are in a typical Chinatown local eatery.  The portions of the other dishes are small and are hit and miss.  So my suggestion is basically to do what I do:  don't order them.  

Order the clay pot rice.  The selections of the various types of meat for your clay pot rice is on one page of the menu.  You have to order for two people but it's delicious.  Very few places do clay pot rice well but Bow Hon does.  So give it a try.  If you choose to order other items on the menu, then you're on your own.  

Stick with the clay pots.  They give you lettuce with oyster sauce on the house with your clay pot rice so you get your dose of veggies along with your choice of meats such as preserved duck, chinese sausage, etc.  Then after you've eaten all the meats and rice, they will make a soup from your clay pot.  It's a simple soup.  They put some basil and let the clay pot flavor take over.  Don't forget to ask them to make the soup.  It's great.

This is not earth-shattering food.  It's very typical Chinese cuisine so your life will not be changed by coming here but you will enjoy a good deal.
author: Chrys S.

description: Terrific, authentic place for (menu-based, not cart) dim sum (ask for the dim sum menu).  Honey walnut chicken was super flavorful and tender-plump.  BBQ steamed pork buns a bit small but served hot and delicious.  All the steamed buns and potstickers were incredibly flavorful and fresh. Quick service.  Loved it.
author: Alex G.

description:
Not terrible...but definitely not good.  The food looked and sounded good, so we figured we'd give it a chance despite its tourist trap potential.  We chose poorly.

Pot stickers were drenched in oil, the squid was definitely not fresh, and I do believe they charged us for the rice (which, incidentally, I wouldn't have even bothered ordering, save for the waitress asking me what kind of rice I wanted, prompting me to say, "Steamed, I guess.").  The final dish was Chinese broccoli with beef--actually not bad at all, but nothing to write home about.  The veggies seemed pretty fresh, at least.

Service was also really good--surprisingly attentive server, who seemed nice enough.

All in all, very little to complain about specifically - the food just wasn't very tasty.  Not much else to say about it.
author: Brian F.

description: Absolutely HATED their dim sum. For the quality they had, they were ridiculously priced. For 3 pieces of any dim sum, it was $2.65! Didn't order anything from their actually dish menu, but it looked over priced as well. The dim sum lacked seasoning. The rice paper they used to steam was overcooked and too soft, it was like eating a soggy fruit roll up. Do no recommend coming here for their dim sum.
author: Kay R.

description: Our meal was very good: vegetable chow mein, shrimp dumplings, and pork siu mai. Had dim sum elsewhere beforehand so this was a nice light lunch
author: adrian h.

description: Looking for food while going through Chinatown.  We decided to go and and we were not disappointed. A good sign is when other Chinese people are also wasting there. I got the won ton soup which had a flavorful broth. I decided to try the flat noodles with egg and prawn and it was delicious. My friend got a noodle bowl with soup, shrimp and vegetables and she enjoyed it also.  A nice meal reasonably priced.
author: Sandra M.

description:
Sooooooooooooooo bad.
Do not go there, never,never,,,
Absolutely terrible paking duck, their dim sum. 
For the quality they had, they were ridiculously priced. 
Do no recommend coming here for their foods.
I asked manager and owner contack number but they never give me.
Go back to home!!!
author: Jay P.

description:
I honestly do not understand people who come to an authentic Chinese place that specializes in clay pot food, order something like egg rolls or sweet and sour chicken, and leave unhappy. I have 5 words for you. Go. To. Chinese. Buffet. Seriously. You will get the right stuff at the right price. Trying to get Chinese American food here is a grave mistake and a waste of your money. And yes, dim sum portions are small. And expensive if you get them not in a dedicated dim sum restaurant.

Now, to the review. I think Bow Hon is great if you like real Chinese food and are not afraid to experiment. Today we tried among other things a dish with a really funny name. Something like 'Sauteed Bok Choy In Person' (likely, a bad translation). It was just steamed Chinese cabbage but with a very delicious sauce. We ate it down to the last leaf. We also got a seafood clay pot (too much fishcake and tofu, not enough seafood, but still nicely tasting), steamed fish in wine sauce (only okay for me but my friend loved it), and sesame balls (soft and yummy). 

So my recipe is be brave, try new, share with friends or family, and you'll be rewarded. But if you have conservative taste for buffet food this is not a place to go.
author: Sergey F.

description:
All I have to say is that you have to try the sashimi/raw fish salad and their clay pots which are pretty much what Bow Hon is known for. It was a fairly large space with 2 floors and they had a cool dumbwaiter (aka food elevator) that transported food from the kitchen downstairs to the tables upstairs where we were. 

Service was decent with our waitress checking on us regularly but she tended to forget things we requested and the food didn't come out as quickly compared to other Chinese restaurants I have been to. The floor was super sticky for some reason too so our chairs were difficult to move around most of the evening. At least no one left hungry after our meal here, that's for sure!

The special sashimi salad platter (not sure of the price but probably close to $40) was amazing! There was a zesty lemon flavor with a lot of crunch.  It was comprised of fried wonton strips, fried vermicelli, red pickled ginger, roasted peanuts, cilantro, ground peppercorns, and fresh pieces of raw fish/squid. I came back for seconds! I think it comes in smaller sizes as well but this platter fed 9 of us. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/AtU4bqmaF5Aw3zc1_n68Kg?select=dBntiM9bb-802gk6LdL48w) Here's a close up shot. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/AtU4bqmaF5Aw3zc1_n68Kg?select=-KNJzmfGtaAsCEXJYrZgag)

Some other dishes we ordered were clams in a black bean sauce and Chinese broccoli with beef (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/AtU4bqmaF5Aw3zc1_n68Kg?select=8Ts9R-3cA_Awdv3lGywYgQ). Both were fairly large portions and tasted great! The 3rd dish accompanied our clay pot order which included preserved duck and Chinese sausage...yum! They cooked it with the meat on top of the rice so that the flavors infused into it (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/AtU4bqmaF5Aw3zc1_n68Kg?select=5RFGWo-T41GFaQJHQ5BlMg). The rice was piping hot, delicious, and went well with the salty, preserved meats. After the rice was all done, our waitress poured some soup into the clay pot to make porridge with the hardened rice on the bottom. So good! Totally worth $19 since it fed so many of us and we got 2 courses in one. 

Needless to say, my belly was bursting when it was time to leave. I want to try their other clay pots next time! Cash only of course.
author: Karen Y.

description: We were craving some dim sum, and after being pestered for about half a block by some lady that works here we decided to try it. She said they served dim sum and that it was "very good" and "much better than the other restaurants around the area which are tourist traps". This was around lunch time on a Friday by the way. So we go in, didn't get served tea right away which was kind of strange. And then realized that we had to request it (it's $1.50 btw!) Tea is usually free at other Chinese places so I thought it was weird! We ordered many of the dim sum dishes- which were all really bad. The portions were tiny for $3.95 each dish??? Everything we had tasted old, and not fresh at all. I think it was definitely frozen and they simply heated it up. But even the frozen stuff you get at grocery stores taste better. The menu was misleading. The pictures shows 4 har gow, 4 siu mai, etc. But in the tiny text written below it in Chinese it says there are 3. It was so bad that we couldn't even finish our food even though it was such a tiny portion. Perhaps the other food on the menu is a much safer bet when you're eating here. But if you're craving dim sum, DO NOT come here.
author: J K.

description: bad price for what it offers. the quantity is small, quality is below average and price is high.
author: Yu M.

description:
[04/21/2012, 9:00pm]

We were at the beach and there was a two-hour wait at Sam's, so we decided to eat in Chinatown on our way back. We were wandering around and decided to eat here. The waitress/hostess was really friendly and there were a few people inside eating so we thought, why not? We ordered the Lobster with ginger and scallion and the combination chow mein. 

Lobster:
We took a really long time to order, because we just didn't know what to get. I asked her if they had lobster and whether it was fresh, and she said yes, that it was fresh and in the basement. Whatever that means. And no, I didn't see it crawling around in the fish tank in front. Anyway, but we got it. It came out like three minutes later. Don't ask me how, because I have no idea how they cooked it so fast. And it was actually pretty good, the flavor that is. The lobster itself was pretty fresh, the only thing was the size - it was TINY! I swear that someone in the kitchen was eating the other half of our lobster. I pointed out to my husband that there was only one big claw, and that the other "claw" didn't really look like a claw. But whatever, it was good, and we were hungry, but we finished it in like five bites.

Chow mein:
This was okay, not very good, but not bad. Again, the portion was tiny. Plenty of meat and veggies, but hardly any noodle. 

Summary:
The flavor was good, service was quick, but we were still super hungry after we finished eating. It was kind of disappointing. The portions are really small. I'd rather they just charge a little more and give decent portions. I hate the feeling of wanting more after you've just went out to eat. Oh well. Will we return? Probably not.  And they do accept credit cards here, with no fee.
author: Michele E.

description: Place is OKAY!!! Nothing special!! Food is authentic but that's it. If you need to go to the bathroom, be prepared to walk up 3 flights of stairs because the bathroom is upstairs!!! On a side note, there's no toilet or bathroom tissue in there!!!
author: Carlos C.

description:
Clay pot rice takes 15-20mins in the kitchen so I skipped it in lieu of faster stuff.  Ordered the steamed minced pork with egg yolk......TO DIE FOR!!  It is so super delicious with rice, the taste will totally take you down memory lane to your little old chinese grandma's kitchen.  Steamed dim sum dishes are also excellent.  

you will surely get a warm fuzzy and full belly feeling as you leave...especially at the smallness of the bill.
author: Mia W.

description:
I went here a while ago (...okay, three years ago) and they were just horrible. The hostess sat us away from everyone else--I felt like it was a racial thing because we were the only non-chinese people in the restaurant. The food took forever to reach our table (and it wasn't even that good). When we walked up to pay, the hostess said that we didn't leave tip and we were supposed to. Um...we don't have to do shit; especially if the service and food was horrible. 

I guess they have to badger/force each customer to pay tip because people aren't willingly leaving one... hmm... I wonder why.

Screw this place.
author: Juliette R.

description:
I went here with friends and their one-year-old daughter. I had the pineapple sweet and sour chicken and my friends had the chicken and snap peas and the chicken and broccoli. We also ordered the sweet egg custard.

My meal was ok. It was a pretty typical American-Chinese sweet and sour dish, although I really didn't like the pineapple (and I usually love pineapple, but the flavor was off). My friends seemed to like their food. They liked the egg custard as well, but I wasn't so hot about that either.

Probably a pretty safe place to go with kids, but nothing special - I think you could definitely find better in Chinatown.
author: Ruthie L.

description:
This is family dining but not any family you really want to eat at...  This is the aunt in your family who "can't" cook and is husbandless.

Maybe they are making the cash from the tourist.  I dunno.  The only somewhat acceptable dish is the bean curd over chinese greens (despite the oiliness).  Sometimes taking chances at a new restaurant just doesn't pay.
author: Laurence H.

description:
Walkin around chinatown in sf and we were starved. out of the numerous hole in the walls we stumbled into this one. it looked packed but the waitress opened the door and said "come in come in we have room!!" 
the girls and i thought..."WHERE?!?!?!" 

she led us up a loooong staircase and it was an upstair dining area. we got the veggie chowmein, mongolia beef, and some tea. the way they transport the meals from downstairs to upstairs is amazing! im thinking its more of a trash chute/elevator thing but still cool.

the food was decent nothing out of the ordinary. portions were a LITTLE small considerin its chinese food ...but then again it was lunch...
author: Carolyn C.

description:
Before this trip I had no idea what a clay pot was.. but then again my friends and I weren't looking for a claypot dish either.

We were on the hunt for some simple dim sum to celebrate my gal Cara completing her LSATs.

So we just picked this place at random because the one menu we could read said they had dim sum.  Woohoo!

This place was just what we needed- when we needed it.  Somewhere warm, with tea, a table and some food. 

Plus this place was completely empty at 3pm on Saturday.. so it worked for us.. not having a line- as a sign of good food- not a good one.

So we ordered the shrimp dumplings, scallop dumplings, seseme balls,spicy noodle roll and egg rolls.  All with some hot tea and we were set.  Myself, Hafiza and Cara spent a good two hours just chatting away and randomly nibbling and sipping tea.

This place was perfect for it.  If I had known the place was a Supa Fly clay pot place.. and I hadn't just had a huge lunch.. I would have ordered a clay pot.

But for what it was the dum sim was ok.. nothing to rave about.. but the company and a warm spot to chat more than made up for that.

Will I be back?.. Hmm maybe just to try the claypot.
author: Alicia A.

description: Wow ! Geoff G., you took me back to one of my favorite Chinese restaurants in SF, and THE place for clay pot specialties ! I would frequent BH at least once a week when I lived in The City in the early/mid 1980s. With a simmering clay pot full of seafood , perk, and chicken to enjoy, it was a welcome respite from a long walk in the cool evening air. How happy I am to know that BH is still in business ! May it outlive us both !
author: T. Arthur P.

description: This place was average.  Average service, average food, average setting.  That about sums it up.
author: J R.

description: Bow Hon was definitely a pleasant surprise!  Don't be fooled by the outside of the restaurant.  We looked at the menu and saw the wonderful dishes and knew this was the place.  Inside - clean and smelling so appetizing!  We had the dinner for 3 which was very reasonably priced for SF.  I have to say, the spring rolls were the best I've had in a long time.  The mushroom chicken chow mien, beef broccoli and pork fried rice were delicious...  wash it down with ice cold Tsingtao - even better!!!  I think Bow Hon restaurant is a diamond in the rough.
author: Rudy G.

description:
TERRIBLE! The service was awful. After sitting for 30+ minutes with absolutely NOTHING to eat in front of me (all I ordered was steamed rice, not a difficult order) while my husband finished his fried squid, we asked for his Mongolian beef and my rice to go. It took saying "excuse me" about five times before our waiter acknowledged us and he ran off without even letting my husband get the words "can we get our food to go please" out of his mouth. 10 minutes later he brought our bag. We got back to our hotel room and though they had given us napkins and forks, they gave us no soy sauce. 
As my husband began eating his Mongolian beef, he saw that in the corner of the Styrofoam box was a pile of cigarette ashes. I guess that was our punishment for requesting service.
And yes, we were the only white people in the place who didn't have Chinese people also at the table, so I agree it may have been a racial thing with us too.
If it wasn't for tourists, Chinatown would be called Ghosttown instead, so they may want to think about how they are treating their "customers."
author: Jill M.

description:
CASH ONLY!  his place is ok for tourist, but for SF locals and people in the Bay Area it's NOT a destination.

There have been a few chowhound reports raving about this place so was pretty excited to finally get to try it, should have known better.

These are the dishes we got:

1. House special shunde delux fish salad.  Small $12.95; Medium $23.80; Large $38.80.  i think we got a medium $23.80 and it was Huge.  Lots of fried vermicelli noodles, chip like thingies, and red ginger, and some raw fish.  Fish was ok, but not enough of it..too much filler stuff and not worth getting.

2. Rice noodles w/ beef & soy sauce $5.95 - well, I ordered it as dry-style beef chow fun so this is the closest I could find on the menu.  It was good, but kinda small.  Two ppl can finish it.

3. water spinach w/ fermented bean curd (on choi fu yee) think it was between $6.50-$8.95.  It was good, not great.

4. braised brisket of beef baked clay pot $8.50- not enough beef brisket, was tender, chinese turnips were fine.  Doesn't come w/ rice, u would need to order separate.

Took forever to get our food, got charged $1.5 for what I think was hot tea though we didn't ask for it, that's EVIL.  Didn't get any free house soup nor fortune cookies though others got them.  Evil.  Total for 4 dishes $41.55 before tip.  Evil.

There's an upstairs dining room that you have to walk by the kitchen to get to, weird.

CASH ONLY.
author: Ann L.

description: Really hospitable place with really good food. Roast duck was a treat! Other good stuff we ordered. .scallop and prawn dim sum and singapore noodles. All round great experience !
author: Kumeshan S.

description:
This place is nothing like the original owners of long ago. Sadly the quality of a family runned restaurant is lost. 
The food is just ok. Nothing special. The service is the same.
author: Stormtrooper N.

description:
We wouldn't have even given this place a second glance had not the waitress snag us and reel us in when she saw us.

We were only in the mood for soup. Wonton and Chicken and corn soup. The broths were flavorful (especially the Wonton--clear and clean with generous wontons and liberal fresh green onions), hot and the portions were perfect for what we needed. Sure soup can be hard to mess up but If the rest of the food was this quality, then there is much to look forward to.

And it's true that there was virtually no decor to speak of but quick service, a good-looking menu had us thinking about coming back next time we were in the area.

NOTE: Cash only now.
author: Glenn H.

description:
I've recently started getting into the habit of walking around in Chinatown on my lunch break and picking a place randomly.  Today, it landed me in Bow Hon.

It's okay.  We had the BBQ beef with noodles, beef chow fun, and the beef won ton soup.  Clearly we're all vegetarians.  The food is somewhat greasy (actually, very greasy) but at least it's a flavorful tasty.  The portions were okay-priced too - $8.95 for each of our items.  However, they all arrived at different times (each one about 4 minutes after the other), so we all had to wait for the last person's dish to come out before eating.

My beef chow fun had large pieces of tender beef, bean sprouts, and fat rice noodles.  In my opinion, the noodles were overcooked and they were stuck together, so it was hard for me to evenly portion out the beef and sprouts with the noodles.  I've had much better chow fun for cheaper, but for a quick lunch, this was decent enough.

The service is relatively unattentive, but expected for a place like this right?  The menu is large, and from what I've been reading about this place, I should try the clay pot dishes next time, which I definitely will.

Total for 3 people = $29.45 before tip.
author: Tori S.

description:
Ordered take-out: sweet and sour pork:

There was a medium amount of rice and a small amount of sweet and sour souce.  

Within the souce were 5 pieces of pure fat and 2 pieces of  actual meat.  There were also a few  small pieces of onion. 

 ZERO  BOWS FOR BOW HON!
author: Manuela C.

description:
You would think that in Chinatown, one could find some really good Chinese restaurants. Sadly to say, I haven't found an outstanding one. 

I saw Bow Hon featured on one of Martin Yan's travel episodes. So my friends and I thought it would be a good choice. We ordered hot and sour soup, sweet and sour pork, claypot chicken and fried fish. Everything was average except the soup. The soup was tasteless and really thick. It was the worst hot and sour soup I've ever had.

Also, halfway through our dinner the workers pushed a huge trash can out from the kitchen through the dining area to get to the street. It was gross.
author: liz s.

description: As awful as Chinese food can be. I ordered Hong Kong iced tea or something and a lady brought it to the front door. It wasn't even prepared on site. Is that legal? Our server had a really bad cold and kept wiping her nose with the back of her hand. I never once saw her wash her hands. Our food arrived and the only word to describe the 5 dishes is oily. We could barely eat it. Just awful. We paid the exorbitant bill and limped out of the place smacking ourselves for not knowing better. Later that night I experienced chills, stomach cramps and malaise. We ended up missing a live show we had tickets for because I couldn't make it off the sofa. This place robbed me twice. Never again.
author: Amanda R.

description:
I like the clay pots here; they are tastey and smell good. Many of the claypots are cooked with wine; probably shaoshing wine. Very aromatic. This is the type of food to enjoy and take your time, delight your senses and eat slowly; your tummy will be rewarded. No business talk!         Let the food talk to your mouth.
Been here a few times over the last two years: consistently good clay pots. I think it's good Chinese food. Try a clay pot with Roast pork and bean curd( tofu); or just a full veggie clay pot. Yummy.
  The big version of the clay pot of pai-kwot and bitter melon is deelicious, very yummy.
Decor: clean and minimal.
author: Bert K.

description:
Hands-down the WORST CHINESE RESTAURANT IN CHINATOWN!!!

It takes hard work on many fronts to attain this notorious distinction...

- I noticed people complain about the decor... (I laughed at that, since Chinese restaurants and good decor are mutually exclusive IMHO)

- Others complained about the service... (but I regularly visit many Chinese restaurants where the food more than makes up for the surly service)

- The food was overpriced, which it was, but, compared to a nice French Restaurant, still very cheap (Of course in a nice French restaurant one gets nice decor, service and food... missing in this place)

- The food was bad... (but many tourist-traps serve lousy food and survive because of their location... as this one does)

The specialty of this place is the way they treat customers who do not have cash on them. I was unaware that they did not accept credit cards (cheating Uncle Sam seems standard business practice at this place).

They did not accept a credit card for my bill (20 measly dollars), they GRABBED MY BICYCLE as collateral, yelling at me and treating me like a common thief!!!

I called 911, when the cops came, I went to the ATM a block away, gave them their miserable $20 and walked out with a bellyful of insults.

I cannot imagine a business putting in all that effort to alienate their customers. If there was a Yelp rating for that, they would win TEN STARS!
