(Oh and by the way, when I pulled out my phone to call the cops, the counter guy said "if you no want to leave bike, you leave phone, its good one") @#$#$%$#%%^%^
author: T S.

description:
I am Thaisan..........so let me tell you..... this is as close as it is going to get to my roots. You just need to know what to order when you come here. You can't order the mayo shrimp, the pot stickers, the broccoli chicken/beef, and sweet and sour pork. 

You need to order the clay pot. The Chinese sausage (don't think dirty) and preserved duck in clay pot is thaisan soul food. It is probably the unhealthiest clay pot of them all but it is damn good, it is my comfort food. I came here with two of my friends the other night after a birthday party at Mr. Bing's..........that is another story in itself. We strolled in here and it is your typical Chinatown restaurant. A little worn down, bright lights, dated paint, tables and chairs but you know what???...........it works. I ordered their daily fresh vegetables, their chicken in a clay pot and we had a feast. 

Don't expect this to be a Tommy Toy's, Koi Palace, Mayflower..........This is your run of the mill, hole in the wall restaurant that serves great southern comfort Thaisan food.  It is a little pricey for Chinatown standards but it is good.  I will try the other clay pot restaurant down the block next  week.  Heard from Michael C. that it was a lot better than this place.  We will see!!!!
author: jason g.

description:
Came in on chilly night for claypot rice.  We ordered in advance but still have to wait as it was a busy night.  Service was attentive even they were extremely busy. (nothing was opened in downtown as it was christmas day)

Food: ****
We ordered a clay pot rice with assorted smoked pork/sausage/duck and a stir fry fish fillet with bean sprout.  Both are good.  It could use little less msg though.  The smoked pork tastes like homemade version.

Price: ***
It's not the cheapest but it's reasonable.  About $17 for a huge clay pot rice that comes with a plate of veg. and rice soup made out of crispy rice left at the bottom of clay pot.  Enough for 2-person for sure.  Another fish fillet stir try is about $9-10.

Service: ****
It's chaotic night but the waitresses and cooks managed to pull it through.  


Place: ** 1/2
It's really just okay.  Nothing fancy.  Our table is not even balanced.

Parking: **
It's chinatown.  Don't expect easy parking during rush hour. 

They even have dessert and dim sum on menu but didn't have room to try any of those.
author: Penguin L.

description: Had the steam chicken, spare ribs with Chinese broccoli , pan fried noodles , thought it was OK, nothing special
author: C L.

description:
Bottom Line.

Pretty Cheap. Small, simple place. Good food. Small Portions. Reasonable waiting time. 

Extended Version

Ok, I like the place, I would definitely go again. It was a little difficult to find but the pricing on the dim sum caught our attention. Small cute "hole in the wall" kind of place. The place had several takers though which is good, if the place is empty, it kind of turns me off. Tried dumplings, BBQ pork and spring rolls. All good, great use of spices and sauces. The prices were reasonable, rang cheap and the bill was not high but the portions were pretty small. Cash only, but it's to be expected. If you are in the neighbor hood try it out. 

Walked away nodding in approval, still a little hungry. Clean plate.

Three stars. 

It's Good.
author: Vanessa R.

description:
As a disclaimer I am now 30 and I remember visiting here as early as about age 5 when they had a kumquat tree inside and would give me fortune cookies galore.  It was (under the prior owner) a mainstay throughout my childhood, and (under the current owner) remains a place I visit whenever I am in the city.  I am somewhat saddened by how poorly Bow Hon is reviewed.

First, it helps if one brings their expectations inline with atmosphere.  PF Changs has very nice restrooms and readily accepts credit cards - but their food (while good in some respects) is absolutely unauthentic.  Bow Hon has gum stuck to the underside of tables, cheap decor, horrible bathrooms, and railings sticky to the touch leading to them (just like those found in China), it is staffed with, cooked by, and filled with ethnic Chinese.

Second, most reviewers are ordering the wrong dishes.  If you are thinking of ordering pot stickers, beef with broccoli, cashew chicken, a pu pu platter, fried rice, etc do yourself a favor and get it by the scoop somewhere.  Otherwise print the handy menu below and order a dish or two off it on your next visit as these I personally swear by:

  crab with ginger and scallion.
  clams in black bean sauce.
  chin min (sp?) hong kong style (with seafood and vegetables).

  Others which are less heavenly than the above but which are great in their own right:
  steamed fish (ie sea bass)
  salt and pepper prawns
author: Nalin S.

description:
Ugh.
This place sucks. First off, it's overpriced considering the quality and quantity of the food. Like my egg rolls came in this tiny ridiculous bite size rolls (like frozen food you get at a convenient store).
The rice comes in a smaller bowl. Dishes come in smaller plate too. And lastly, the food taste so ugh, not good.
Tourist trap!
author: Gabriele A.

description:
This is one of my favorite Chinese restaurants in SF. Every time I visit the Bay area I must stop by this one. The food there was so amazing that after I came back from SF three days I still couldn't forget how delicious the food was. I would highly recommend you visit this restaurant if you are looking for some authentic Chinese food. 

Taste of the food and authenticity ***** 5 stars
My top dishes are the following:

The 'Eggs and Pig Knuckles with Ginger and Vinegar' is the BEST! If you're willing to venture yourself to try something exotic rather than the regular Chinese food (fried rice, pork chop/ kung pao chicken, etc), you can try this dish and you'll be surprise! learn more abt this dish @http://bit.ly/99UKRZ This dish is really good for your health because it supply calcium and provide protein. 

2nd favorite dishes: Steam Chinese cabbage. 
Tis dish is super well prepared which you have to allow 15-20 mins prep time. The cabbage is steamed in a bamboo steamer with a layer of foil paper at the bottom, and some minced pork and some green bell pepper on top, this combination made the dish taste terribly good. I've never tasted anything comes close to this. 

Service **** 4 stars
The services was very  friendly and efficient. The waitress kept checking with us and let us know when will the food be ready which is very nice!

Place *** 3 stars 
Very basic and nothing fancy. But the place is really big that they have 3 different floors which can accommodate big group of people. 

Parking **** 4 stars
Very convenient. You can park at the chinatown parking garage which is one or two blocks down the street on 728 Pacific Avenue if you can't find any street parking.

Price (varies)
Two people order two main dishes about $25. For the taste of food it's really worth it!  

Additional Tips:

They serve dim sum all day long which is super nice if you're looking for some small Chinese dishes to eat. Dim sum is $1.5 each. 

Bare in mind that this place is CA$H ONLY. Don't forget to bring some $!
author: Chalsea C.

description:
Came here for a takeout. Pretty fast service!

The salt and pepper pork chop was so very fatty yum yum good so I have to skimp on dinner after the lunch. Rice is an extra dollar which was not bad.

Also picked up an iced milk tea which they bought it next door!
author: T L.

description:
This is the place to go in San Francisco for clay pot. It's their specialty and they have excelled at it for years. Avoid anything on the menu that looks like dim sum - it's for the tourists.

Hint- after you finish your clay pot, be sure to ask them to make sizzling rice soup out of the burnt rice on the bottom of the pot. It's the most exciting part of the meal!
author: Patrick Z.

description:
To get a great experience, you have to eat meat and know what to order when you come here. It's a genuine Chinese restaurant, not an Americanized restaurant serving sweet and sour pork.

There is a reason it's called a Clay Pot Restaurant... That's their specialty, and they do an awesome job of it.

Every clay pot we have ordered has been fantastic - the steamed pork ribs in black bean sauce over rice is tantilizing - keep the lid on the pot while you enjoy the first bowl of pork and rice, and then dig to the bottom to get the crisp rice crust that has roasted while you were eating... and dip in sauce. The eggplant and seafood clay pots are likewise delicious. If you like salty meats steamed into rice, they have delicious pots with salted duck, laap cheong, or salted pork belly that is amazing.
author: Anne F.

description: Best clay pot ever! I feel like I'm China!  Me and my family went there a lot, just for the clay pot!
author: Robert L.

description:
The clay pot rices are  overrated..... Also had other dishes, which was very average food... 

The service was good but I am not sure this restaurant really stands out compare to other restaurants in Chinatown...
author: Coco L.

description: Great place to eat. The food is cooked not too salty and not too oily. Just enough ingredients to keep the food tasting good. Had the lobster, beef cubes, and bass. The bass was great but the best about this restaurant is the cashier/server "ah-Zhen" she was a real treat! Having her service made the restaurant much better!
author: James C.

description:
Keane L.: *pulls out credit card*
Hostess: The machine broken.
Keane L.: Just try it.
Hostess: There is ATM outside.
Keane L.: Just try it.
Hostess: Okay, I try it. You have ID?
Keane L.: *shows ID*
(five minutes of staring)
Hostess: Okay, I try it. Oh, it works.

Big surprise. Like riding a taxi.

$70 for four people. This is probably one of the worst Chinese restaurants I've ever been to. Edible food, but my pineapple chicken was skimpy. I don't mean fancy-bistro skimpy, I mean patchy-rat-hair skimpy. I don't know what that means, but maybe you do.
author: Keane L.

description:
lotus root with veggies: it was decent.
mongolian beef: it was decent. 
price: not so decent.
author: NY Y.

description:
I went for Dim Sum... It was okay.

Nothing great, nothing exciting... just.... ok.

I don't think I'd go again... and I definitely think the food was over-priced... The service was decent, though. :)
author: Elle Q.

description:
We should have guessed that the food would suck.  Went with coworkers at lunch and the place was EMPTY.  It's in Chinatown and the place was EMPTY?!!

Go someplace else.  The only thing I can say about the "famous" clay pot dish I had was that it was hot.  Yay...
  :-|
author: Anonymouse C.

description:
I love this place for it's clay pot rice.  I see some of the reviewers gave a lower rating because they ordered food like beef chow fun or fried tofu, but when you walk into a restaurant in Chinatown, you really need to know what to order depending on the restaurant.  The clay pot rice is the best in the Bay Area.  I would suggest anything with Chinese sausage or bacon.  Their taste goes right into the rice and really brings out its flavor.  Each clay pot comes with a dish of veggie, which I think is enough for a meal, since your main dish should be the clay pot rice anyways.  After the meal, they will make a delicious claypot rice soup for free.

I am especially impressed by the service in this restaurant, compared to other Chinese restaurants.  Chinese restaurants are not known for friendly service, but the waitresses here I think are trained with an emphasis on being friendly.  They make suggestions, help you scoop the rice, and makes friendly comments.  I usually don't expect a friendly face at Chinese restaurants, so this is a bonus for me.
author: Jeffrey C.

description:
Whoa, they charge a lot for what you get.... I mean, it's still a cheap eats place in SF, but no wonder I don't come here often at all. I like the sweet and sour pork and that's about it.

The egg flower soup is sketchy, full of tomatoes, peas and carrots.
My teacup had a rice grain stuck on it, with a little bit of leftover lipstick from the previous customer.

Eeewww... :P
author: dj z.

description: Great little gem in Chinatown, went here during Thanksgiving and went to multiple places before settling to eat dinner here.  The frog legs clay pot is the main dish here.  The frogs were fresh and not frozen, the meat literally was like fish, super soft melt off the bone meat.  The waitress gave us a clean lettuce dish for free, which was great to add the greens into our dinner as well.  Sorry didn't update this earlier but definitely will come back to visit again.
author: Viet-shirley T.

description:
Came here for a late dinner on a Sunday night.  This probably isn't the kind of place that the locals go to, but it was late and this was still opened.  Made for a good, warm dinner.

1.  Salt and Pepper Pork Chops - the smallest portion I've ever gottem at any Chinese restaurant of this kind.  But the flavor was very good - savory and spicy, just a bit on the stingy side with the portion.
2.  Tender Greens w/ Oyster Sauce - the greens were very fresh!
3.  Black Pepper Sauce Clams - ironically, they gave us a good amount of clams.  Delicious.
author: Lillian M.

description:
Bow Hon is a small restaurant in the heart of Chinatown..  It's fairly clean and unassuming in its appearance, and one server covers the entire place..

The specialize in clay pot dishes, and when I went, I ordered the "Bow Hon Special" and the "Duck and Taro" clay pots...  The clay pot dishes come hot and sizzlin and were quite tasty..  The steamed rice wasn't quite sticky enough for my taste, but not bad...  The mongolian beef was super good, and the chicken wings we ordered were bland and tasteless...

But, all in all Bow Hon is a decent place to grab some solid Chinese food if you're ever in Chinatown -- it's weird how nobody I know actually goes to Chinatown for Chinese food anymore (so we're trying to hit up some of the places to see if there's anything anyone has missed...)
author: Dennis Y.

description:
I would agree with past reviews that Bow Hon is pricey but you must factor in the location.

My meal there was decent.

We ordered the following:
1) "Special" claypot with frog legs, chinese sausage & mushroom with rice- the legs were chewy & tasty but could have used a bit more mushrooms, the rice afterwards was nice & crunchy like "dol sat bim bim bap" of Korean food which I really enjoyed.

2) Chicken wings with chinese chives- tasty & the cook was nice enough to remove most of the bone.

3) Beef with chinese broccoli- good but nothing special about this plate.

Bow Hon was nice enough to give us a plate of cooked lettuce with oyster sauce for free.
(I guess they were worried about us on having additional veggies in our diet)

So, the bill came to be about $40 for the 3 plates we ordered- again pricey.

Note - Restroom is not wheelchair friendly (located on the 3 floor, nice walk to work up an appetite).

The service was attentive but not a reason to make a second visit soon.
author: Herbert K.

description:
I came here with a group of int'l visitors a few times, and food was always tasty and enjoyable.  We had an array of dishes including the speciality clay pot, the raw fish salad, bokchoy & chicken soup, beef chow fun, salted fish and sliced pork in claypot, with the tasty rice crust.  

A little expensive perhaps, but service was actually...great, the waitress we had was taking care of us wonderfully.
author: Keith M.

description: I got the preserved duck clay pot rice. It's very good and comes with meat and veggie. Portion is good for two people or one with super big appetite.
author: Aimee C.

description:
I broke the Golden Rule of Chinatown eating

...which is, "Never eat anywhere on Grant Avenue." Normally I follow the rule, but I'd heard that Martin Yan of TV cooking fame endorsed Bow Hon, and that they cook good clay pot dishes.  I have now tried three separate clay pot dishes, and none of them were worth recommending. Food here is drenched in sauce and no dishes, clay pot or otherwise, are that great.

They do have an all-Chinese character page on their menu, though, so maybe there's something redeeming hidden there, but probably not.
author: Ian G.

description:
Not surprised that some of you don't get this place, especially if it's not listed in the Michelin guide. For all of you who do get this place, which is a small, unassuming hole in the wall, get the Clay Pot or the raw fish salad here. The only place I know of that will take your 'empty' clay pot and turn it into a fancy 'Fan Dieu', a country style dish that is usually made at home by taking the empty rice pot and browning the crust that is left on the edges, then pouring in water and bringing to a boil. This is eaten at the end of the meal, picking at what is left of the dishes. They step it up here, adding chicken broth, slices of fresh ginger and cilantro, making it another whole meal.
You people with your credit cards....puuuhleez, it's called cash.
author: Arlene C.

description: This place was AWFUL. The service was horrendous. It took us forever. Also, the beef was overcooked (it seemed to have been cooked a few days earlier, and just reheated every day) and the pork was RAW we discovered after diting into what seemed a fully cooked piece. Upon further inspection, almost every piece we had was almost completely raw. DO NOT go here. I had Sweet and Sour Pork of some kind, and also Mongolian Beef.
author: Samantha S.

description:
In search of the untimate clay pot rice ... I have to agree with the other reveiwer and should have heeded instead of listening to my coworker.  I'm told that "Capital" is better.  We had the roast pork, etc. clay pot which was like $18 or some insane amount for rice and a smidgeon of other stuff.  I was disappointed and missed "Children's Day" in Japantown.  Should have eaten in Japantown ... so I defer to this review:  

"The clay pot rices are  overrated..... Also had other dishes, which was very average food..."
The service was good but I am not sure this restaurant really stands out compare to other restaurants in Chinatown...

1 clay pot rice dish and 1 oyster with roast pork non-rice clay pot and the tab was over and around $30 ... rice wasn't crunchy either ... next time I need a Chinese chaperone to order ...
author: Terry A.

description: Came here several times for their clay pot rice, and every single time I left with a happy tummy.  So order the right dish...clay pot rice.
author: Adriana Y.

description:
I wished that I had Yelp'd this place before trying it. The photos in the window looked pretty good but that's apparently not a good way to judge the food.

Ordered simple dim sum dishes and maybe 1 out of 4 wasn't bad, but the other three were FORGETTABLE.

The sticky rice in lotus leaves was not bad but I've had better.
The Shanghai dumplings were flavorless and the exterior was made thicker than usual.
The zhou zhiu (?) dumplings fell apart when trying to eat them & also lacked flavor...and it included peanuts for some reason while it was described as a pork & veggie dumpling.
The friend tofu was okay but not great.

Not giving this place a 2nd chance when there are so many other places in Chinatown.
author: D L.

description: Bow Hon is another small chinese restaurant that reminds me of Po Kee and Chef Hung. I came here Bow Hon Restaurant for lunch in the weekday. The food is not that bad. For me it tasted very good.
author: William B.

description:
Good food, decently priced.  Charged 1.50 for something, which i dont know what it was for. Tea?   1 dollar for a bowl of rice...most places ive been to come with rice. 

-We had tomato beef chow mein, it was good but i was expecting crunchy noodles and not soggy noodles.  
-Also had chicken in gravy clay pot.  It was good. but i thinki can make this at home haha

total bill, $17 and change
author: James T.

description: What was once a family-owned, traditional restaurant has certainly changed. For the high prices, the portions have been considerably reduced. Bow Hon appeals both to tourists unfamiliar with Cantonese cuisine as well as the locals who know how to order. Of all their specialties (dim sum being mostly a tourist gimmick), their clay pot rice is absolutely phenomenal for the winter time. The portion, while still small, is quite flavorful (the mushroom, chicken, and chinese sausage as my favorite), and it comes with a plate of veggies. The added bonus is the burnt rice soup that is added afterwards, which is flavor to be experienced for oneself. I definitely do not think the quality has stood the test of time, but Bow Hon is worth visiting if you're in Chinatown.
author: Travis L.

description: We came in because it was half busy for a Monday which is a good sign. Ywife liked the food, some of which we she hadn't had since hong kong. She thought it was above avg though more costly than it should. I thought it was quite fine considering.
author: Mike S.

description:
I ate here almost one year ago and it was great!  We had soup, fish, clay pot, noodles, lobsters and several veggy dishes.  

It was an absolutely tasty and filling dinner.  This was especially so because we had biked from Fisherman's wharf all the way through Tiburon!  So you bet we were hungry.  

But taking hunger aside, I must say the food was good and this would be one of maybe 2 Chinese restaurants that I would eat in Chinatown.  Since as you know, all the good Chinese restaurants are in the South Bay.
author: Alan T.

description: We came here looking for a sit-down dim sum place at noon in Chinatown and this was the only place that actually had space.  A lot of space... there were lots of empty seats but we were starving so we decided to give it a shot. We had the chicken and corn soup, which as piping hot and pretty tasty, but the rest of the dim sum was only so-so.... the soup dumplings wrappers were so delicate that all the soup had drained out by the time we got to them! I've definitely had better and if I ever come back, maybe I would try the claypot (but they're pretty pricey! ~$17)
author: Grace M.

description:
Looking in from the outside, it looks like a tourist trap. You see a bunch of tourists on the first floor + it's located on Grant Ave.

Believe it or not, it's a favorite of locals - just go up to the second floor because that's where you'll find them.

I think the thing that people don't get is that the 'clay pots' this place is known for is not the 'clay pot dishes' that many people on Yelp are ordering. Like others have said, the 'clay pot dishes' like those with the tofu or beef brisket or duck and taro, etc etc are really kind of well, nasty...

The good stuff is the 'clay pot rice dishes' where the rice is cooked in a clay pot (rather than w/ a rice-cooker) with various types of meat inside. From what I can recall, you can get the clay pot rice w/ either spareribs or chicken and mushroom or frog or a combo clay pot rice with Chinese sausage + salted/dried duck + salted/dried pork. There are probably more varieties on the menu... bbbbuuut, in any case, the combo salted meats clay pot rice is the crowd favorite. The flavor of the meats is cooked into the rice and you get salted-meat-juice infused into the rice. Yum!  

Tip: Try to order in advance since it takes a while to cook the rice in the clay pot. Like someone else mentioned, after you finish the rice, they pour in green onions, cilantro and chicken broth and mix it up w/ the slightly charred rice on the bottom of the pot. Great after-meal treat.

The raw fish salad is pretty good too, although people seem to complain that there's not enough fish. IMHO, too much fish makes the dish unbalanced and not very good... Everywhere you get this dish the fish is not plentiful, that's the way it is - they'd charge an arm and a leg if they put in the amount of fish people are calling for. No thanks.
author: Ken L.

description:
I have to tell you I was sooooooo upset by the time I left this place. I have never been treated so rudely in my life!!! It was so embarrassing, because my children and my out of town family was with me. 

I suggest, if you are ever in the area, walk by, believe me it is not worth it and besides is expensive. They are probably double the price as everyone else around there and the portions are small.
author: Ruth Q.

description: I still would never go here and will continue to ask people not to patronize this restaurant.
author: Patty K.

description: Tried their custard tart and their sponge cake on a late night walk through Chinatown. The custard tart was actually really tasty, I'd say better than Golden Gate Bakery (well, I have never really understood the hype about that place). The sponge cake was super heavenly and they even heated it up for me. It had real flecks of vanilla bean in it and it was sooo light and airy. Gosh I just love the mouthfeel of sponge cake. YUMYUMYUM
author: O K.

description:
I finally stumbled on this restaurant which did happen to be on the main street of Chinatown. It looked quaint, simple, and clean. Didn't feel like any fancy fare for lunch. The menu looked yummy. I did notice there were a lot of sushi restaurants in Chinatown... did not try any of them but didn't notice these on my past visits and wonder if it is a recent phenomenon.

Getting ready to order. I finally decided to try their Dinner Special. Their dinner specials are reasonable, costing about $10/person and include multiple courses.

Read rest of review here if interested, with photos too, from a few weeks ago (Aug 2008):

http://www.starksilvercreek.com/2008/09/in-review-bow-h.html
author: Clinton S.

description: We were in chinatown and chose this place on a whim. The service is pretty good and fast. The food was average, nothing spectcular but not bad either. It was alright, but I think there are better choices.
author: Kevin K.

description: if you love clay pot cooking, find this place!  bubbling earthen casserole with puffy white fish dumpling, black mushrooms,napa cabbage,roast pork in a smoky gravey.( bow hon special)
author: Martin G.

description: Today, my mother, a friend's mother, and I decided to go to Chinatown since we are going to be out of town next weekend for the parade. So, after browsing some bazaars a few doors down, we decided to try Bow Hon. I was anxious to have some of that good Cantonese food, including the Bow Hon special with fish cakes, roasted pork, mushrooms, and cabbage with firm, crispy rice. Well, they have apparently changed owners as the food was bland. We had dry braised string beans, pot stickers, egg rolls, Mongolian beef, and sizzling chicken with gravy in clay pot. The egg rolls were the only good thing with a crispy exterior and filled with fresh vegetables. The sweet and sour sauce was well balanced, not too sweet and not too sour. The service was friendly and efficient. The atmosphere is still the same old world one. There are better places in Chinatown and the rest of the city for that matter.
author: Brian S.

description: Me and some friends came in really hungry. We expected a nice small Chinese restaurant with good prices. Well I'll tell ya, the prices are not that cheap. I ordered the pot stickers and chicken fried rice.  My friends ordered the spare ribs, and the shrimp pot. We ordered drinks. One of my friends ordered a watermelon drink. So my pot stickers came first, and it looked rather pale, so I thought it might have been uncooked. I took a bite, and it wasn't bad. I mean, I've tried much better, but I guess it was a- ok since I was really hungry. The waiter came and brought my 7up, and there was this nasty cruddy stuff on it, and I think she noticed it so she brought it up to the front counter and brought it back cleaner. My fried rice was just average, nothing special, and I thought it was really oily. My friend's water melon drink didnt come so she asked the waiter. The waiter said they had to get the drink next door!! What the hell was that?! So the water gave her water. We didn't expect that, so we were like "she better not charge us for it." So when we were almost done,  that's when they brought over her water melon drink! The bill came out to almost 40 bucks. Totally not worth it, and we are not coming back here again.
author: Monina C.

description: Not one of San Franciscos best. Dead fish in the 'Fresh fish'  tank. Funky overall smell. Bathroom, filthy, on the third floor of a sticky, gunky staircase and handrail. I know people rave about this place, but I have to say...my health is important to me and I wont risk it again in this dirty, filthy place. I went with a friend and both of us were suprised at the condition of the restaurant and the food that came. The food had obvious signs of mold and rot. We refused it and left. That they could even think that was okay to serve showed us their standerds.
author: linda j.

description: Interesting to read the negative reviews about Bow Hon - only one of them seemed to know that the dish to order there is the raw fish salad...  It is stellar.  I'm inclined to agree about the rest of the menu...  don't remember anything worth ordering again except that salad...
author: K. M.

description: bow hon special clay pot with lop chung (chinese sausage) added....keeps me goin
author: dion l.

description: Caveats are that I have not tried that many other places in Chinatown. I must say that it is difficult to read reviews written by other people on Yelp or other "citizen reporter" sites or books to know if you will like a place or not.  Hard to say.  I make at least one trip to Bow Hon every time I come to SF. My meal ends up to be pricey, and I walk out feeling like I've had a great meal, not a waste of money.  That said, I have only ordered particular things: the spiced salt shrimp has been fixed differently on different occasions but then I'm not sure how to order - the one I'm trying for is the one that comes out with the heads on, spicy, and red - last time it came out with some batter on it - not sure why it was different.  Sunde fish salad is excellent, okay, true, not so much fish, but I like the tastes of the peanuts, fish, cilantro, etc. mixed together.  Steamed fish balls were tasty.  I also just got hooked on the minced seafood with lettuce leaf wrap - I suspect there's little actual seafood and a lot of water chestnuts, but I had to go back to Bow Hon again for this on the same business trip.  As something of a reward for helping out with a cultural mis-communication between some French tourists and the hostess/manager, the locals to my left last week gave me a taste of their steamed egg custard with clams dish.  I have not ordered any "standard large chinese restaurant" dishes, and maybe that's why I'm thrilled with the place.  The stuff the French tourists were eating was all gloppy and did not look too terribly appetizing.
author: Andrea P.
